quotes.author: Neil deGrasse Tyson
quotes.quote: The Universe is under no obligation to make sense to you.
quotes.meaning: Nature operates independently of human intuitions or expectations.

quotes.author: William James
quotes.quote: A great many people think they are thinking when they are merely rearranging their prejudices.
quotes.meaning: True critical thought demands confronting one’s assumptions, not just reordering them.

quotes.author: Robert A. Heinlein
quotes.quote: Everything is theoretically impossible until it is done.
quotes.meaning: Many breakthroughs seem impossible until someone demonstrates them in practice.

quotes.author: Isidor Rabi
quotes.quote: Great scientists usually show up when and where in the history of science they are needed.
quotes.meaning: Scientific advances often emerge in response to historical or conceptual necessity.

quotes.author: Vasco Ronchi
quotes.quote: It’s perplexing to see the flexibility of the so-called ‘exact sciences’ which by cast-iron laws of logic … can lead to conclusions which are diametrically opposed to one another.
quotes.meaning: Scientific reasoning, though formal, can yield surprising and conflicting implications.

quotes.author: Carl Sagan
quotes.quote: Science is a self-correcting process. To be accepted, new ideas must survive the most rigorous standards of evidence and scrutiny.
quotes.meaning: Progress in science depends on critique, falsification, and empirical testing.

quotes.author: Carl Sagan
quotes.quote: Science is founded on uncertainty. Each time we learn something new and surprising, the astonishment comes with the realization that we were wrong before.
quotes.meaning: Scientific knowledge evolves by overturning prior assumptions in light of new evidence.

quotes.author: Charles Darwin
quotes.quote: It is not the strongest of the species that survives, nor the most intelligent. It is the one most responsive to change.
quotes.meaning: Adaptability, not mere strength or intelligence, often determines survival in evolving environments.

quotes.author: Charles Darwin
quotes.quote: A language, like a species, when extinct, never… reappears.
quotes.meaning: Cultural and biological extinction is irreversible once history moves on.

quotes.author: Albert Einstein
quotes.quote: If we knew what we were doing, it would not be called research, would it?
quotes.meaning: Research inherently involves exploring the unknown; certainty cannot precede discovery.

quotes.author: Albert Einstein
quotes.quote: God does not play dice with the universe.
quotes.meaning: Einstein rejected randomness in nature, believing in underlying order and determinism.

quotes.author: Marie Curie
quotes.quote: Now is the time to understand more, so that we may fear less.
quotes.meaning: Increasing knowledge reduces irrational fear and enables confident action.

quotes.author: Ernest Rutherford
quotes.quote: If you don't do the best with what you have, you could never have done better with what you could have had.
quotes.meaning: Maximize current resources—there’s no virtue in potential unfulfilled.

quotes.author: Thomas Berger
quotes.quote: The art and science of asking questions is the source of all knowledge.
quotes.meaning: Inquiry and curiosity—posing the right questions—drive discovery and understanding.

quotes.author: Edward Teller
quotes.quote: The science of today is the technology of tomorrow.
quotes.meaning: Scientific breakthroughs become the foundation for future practice and tools.

quotes.author: George C. Lichtenberg
quotes.quote: It is strange that only extraordinary man-made the discoveries which later appear so easy and simple.
quotes.meaning: Genuinely novel insights often seem obvious in hindsight, but are hard to generate.

quotes.author: Randall Jarrell
quotes.quote: I think that one possible definition of our modern culture is that it is one in which nine-tenths of our intellectuals can’t read any poetry.
quotes.meaning: He critiques the narrowing of intellectual life to technical domains at the expense of the humanities.

quotes.author: Aimé Césaire
quotes.quote: Poetic knowledge is born in the great silence of scientific knowledge.
quotes.meaning: Poetry and science are complementary modes of knowing, each illuminating the other’s gaps.

quotes.author: Charles M. Schulz
quotes.quote: My life has no purpose, no direction, no aim, no meaning, and yet I’m happy.
quotes.meaning: Meaning can emerge or coexist with uncertainty and lack of grand narratives.

quotes.author: Jacob Bekenstein
quotes.quote: Sometimes theories are smarter than their inventors.
quotes.meaning: The consequences of a theory may exceed the anticipations or intentions of its creator.
